hints.content: Start by understanding the definitions of GCD (Greatest Common Divisor) and LCM (Least Common Multiple). These two mathematical concepts are crucial for calculating the factor score of the array.
Remember that the factor score is calculated as the product of the LCM and GCD of the elements in the array. Make sure you can compute these values for any given array.
Consider how removing an element from the array affects both the GCD and LCM. Removing an element can potentially increase or decrease these values, which will affect the factor score.

To find the maximum factor score, you will need to evaluate the factor score for the original array and for each possible array formed by removing one element. Think about how to systematically do this.
When calculating the GCD and LCM after removing an element, you can use helper functions. Python provides built-in functions for GCD, but you may need to implement LCM yourself.
Keep in mind that if you remove an element, the remaining array must still have at least one element. The factor score of an empty array is defined as 0.
Consider edge cases, such as when the array has only one element. In this case, removing that element would lead to an empty array, resulting in a factor score of 0.
You might want to precompute the GCD and LCM of the entire array first. Then, when you remove an element, you can quickly compute the new GCD and LCM of the remaining elements.
Think about how you can efficiently calculate the GCD and LCM of the remaining elements after removing an element. Using a loop to recompute these values each time may not be optimal.
Finally, after calculating the factor scores for all possible arrays (original and those with one element removed), return the maximum factor score found. Make sure to handle all cases correctly.

questionNotes: The factor score of a single number is the number itself for both GCD and LCM.
The factor score of an empty array is 0.
